text:
I'm gradually moving out of a content-focused role and into a community-focused role, but content still plays an important part of it.

What I'm riffing on: Pooling community insights, knowledge, stories, et cetera into a neatly organized repository of useful information. Something that is distinct from traditional content marketing (voice of the brand) and customer care (break/fix or customer success with a product focus).

elements.text:

text: Definitely thinking about this at my work. I call it our User Education initiative, because it’s not quite customer support and not traditional content. We’re trying to figure out how to incorporate our user & advocate community, too, as that’s something they’ve asked for. Communities can be tricky, because then you have to invest resources into moderating, cleaning up & updating threads, etc. But perhaps that would be worth it, depending on how engaged and content-productive your users are!

text: We're running into many issues on the finance/procurement side. However, our largest roadblock right now is the AB5 bill that was recently passed. We have many writers based in CA, and our Legal team just let us know we'd have to stop all work with them very soon (as they're "hitting the limit").

text:
I'll often ask the person to put together more information. "What do you think that would look like? Could you pull together some recommendations" etc.

If they actually do it (usually they don't), I know it's important enough to look at. This probably applies more to in-house.

text:
> many writers based in CA
Yeah, had a similar issue here. We just kept tabs on CA writers who we didn’t want to part with, and prioritized working with non-CA freelancers otherwise.

elements.text: many writers based in CA

text:
I’m reminded of an anecdote from Creativity, Inc., where work on _The Incredibles_ movie was getting bogged down with the director’s flights of fancy. So they decided to stick popsicle sticks to a wall with Velcro. Each represented a person-week, and sticks would be lined up next to a particular character for easy reference. So if the director (Brad Bird) wanted a change to Elastigirl, the producers would point to the wall and say, “Where are you going to take the stick from? Because we only have so many.”

I love how simple and direct their solution was. Of course, everyone has to be on board with it first

elements.text: I’m reminded of an anecdote from Creativity, Inc., where work on
The Incredibles

movie was getting bogged down with the director’s flights of fancy. So they decided to stick popsicle sticks to a wall with Velcro. Each represented a person-week, and sticks would be lined up next to a particular character for easy reference. So if the director (Brad Bird) wanted a change to Elastigirl, the producers would point to the wall and say, “Where are you going to take the stick from? Because we only have so many.”

I love how simple and direct their solution was. Of course, everyone has to be on board with it first

text: I'm approaching a scope creep issue myself. Tech company asked me to write up one blog for $150. Cool. But the four video interviews took way too many hours to transcribe... that piece was 1200 words and turned in just over 1 week ago. They haven't paid me yet, are still reviewing the first piece, and are asking if I'm interested in writing another blog. This is my first time with an ongoing freelance situation (rather than one-off projects) and there's no contract in place... How do I get paid and continue working with them? What's the best contract to use?

elements.text: I'm approaching a scope creep issue myself. Tech company asked me to write up one blog for $150. Cool. But the four video interviews took way too many hours to transcribe... that piece was 1200 words and turned in just over 1 week ago. They haven't paid me yet, are still reviewing the first piece, and are asking if I'm interested in writing another blog. This is my first time with an ongoing freelance situation (rather than one-off projects) and there's no contract in place... How do I get paid and continue working with them? What's the best contract to use?

text:
First off, ask them to pay before taking up the next project. Also, $150 is too less if you're doing 4 interviews. That takes up a lot of time alone and on top of that you've to write the blog.

I'd suggest, if possible, to go with a 1099 contract. Otherwise, a simple contract with payment terms, deliverables & ETAs should be good enough.

elements.text:
First off, ask them to pay before taking up the next project. Also, $150 is too less if you're doing 4 interviews. That takes up a lot of time alone and on top of that you've to write the blog.

I'd suggest, if possible, to go with a 1099 contract. Otherwise, a simple contract with payment terms, deliverables & ETAs should be good enough.

text: Yeah, I asked for $150 before knowing the total number of interviews. Rookie mistake, I guess. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Yeah, I asked for $150 before knowing the total number of interviews. Rookie mistake, I guess.

text: Happened to me multiple times. I generally share the questions with them and ask them to interview the folks. Then I listen to the calls and look the notes they took. Saves me a lot of time and explanation as to why I'm charging for 30 mins calls.

text:
More of a copywriting than content question, but does anybody have tips for standardizing copy? (Or insight about whether or not that is even a worthwhile endeavor?)

My company has a generalized messaging framework we use (the StoryBrand BrandScript), but we are looking to get more granular and standardize common language. For example, standardizing the use of ‘postal mail’ vs. ‘paper mail’ or “searchable PDFs” vs. “digital files.” Our ultimate goal is to make it super easy for anybody in the company to create assets, and reduce time spent going back and forth on what word to use in an ad or email.

I’m racking my brain thinking about how to even start this process. I know it will require a lot of testing and likely be ongoing. I’m also not sure how to go about it in a way that still allows for enough variation that we don’t end up always saying the same thing

text:
I think what you're talking about is brand guidelines. 

There are a lot of them you can follow. MailChimp has a good one: <https://styleguide.mailchimp.com/|https://styleguide.mailchimp.com/>

attachments.title: Welcome to the Mailchimp Content Style Guide | Mailchimp Content Style Guide
attachments.text: Guidelines and resources for web writers and editors. Includes: voice and tone, grammar, web style, social media, email newsletters, blog posts, legal content, technical content, accessibility, translation, copyright, and more.
attachments.fallback: Mailchimp: Welcome to the Mailchimp Content Style Guide | Mailchimp Content Style Guide

elements.text:

text:
I love this problem so much! Naming things is hard, but something I find weirdly satisfying :heart:

I wrote about my process doing this several years ago: <https://medium.com/@janessalantz/terms-we-use-48822ac15891?source=friends_link&sk=52a326ac3f35d20aa053dd3de71fa450>

It's dated, but mostly holds up. The article focuses on category names, but the process is similar all the way down.

I'm doing this work again in my current role and planning to eventually create a vocabulary list as part of our content style guide that states the terms we use and why.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

attachments.title: Terms We Use
attachments.text: This post is part of the Brand Messaging for Startups Framework, an open-source marketing project. Contributions are welcome :)

elements.text: I love this problem so much! Naming things is hard, but something I find weirdly satisfying
I wrote about my process doing this several years ago:

It's dated, but mostly holds up. The article focuses on category names, but the process is similar all the way down.

I'm doing this work again in my current role and planning to eventually create a vocabulary list as part of our content style guide that states the terms we use and why.

text: Yup, you need brand guidelines or as we call them, editorial style guides. We define voice and tone, specific language/terms to use or not use, and common grammar issues. We'll also put some example copy in there and our brand promise/messaging for value props

elements.text: Yup, you need brand guidelines or as we call them, editorial style guides. We define voice and tone, specific language/terms to use or not use, and common grammar issues. We'll also put some example copy in there and our brand promise/messaging for value props

text: In the future, you can use an AI transcription service like Temi to transcribe the interviews (the cost is 25 cents per audio minute) or you could ask the client to send you transcripts of the interview. But I agree that $150 for a blog that includes 4 interviews isn’t a competitive rate. Are you sure you want to keep working with this client? If you do, going forward I’d say get exact details on the scope of work before you quote them a price. Then send them a contract or statement of work (SOW) that you both agree to.

elements.text: In the future, you can use an AI transcription service like Temi to transcribe the interviews (the cost is 25 cents per audio minute) or you could ask the client to send you transcripts of the interview. If you do, going forward I’d say get exact details on the scope of work before you quote them a price. Then send them a contract or statement of work (SOW) that you both agree to.
